## a.
The goal of this task is to explain why leasing is a zero-sum game.

Now, from the incremental cash flows, we can determine the **Net Present Value** $(\mathrm{NPV})$. Let's recall the formula:
$$
\mathrm{NPV}=
\sum_{t=0}^{n} \frac{R_{t}}{(1+i)^{t}}\\
$$
Where:

$t$ is the number of periods,

$R_{t}$ is the $t$-th net cash inflow-outflows, and;
 
$i$ is the tax bracket.

## b. 
The goal of this task is to show the paradox created by the zero-sum game in a lease.

In part **a.** we used the example of the section to illustrate how to calculate the $\mathrm{NPV}$ of both sides of a lease contract. There we noticed that the $\mathrm{NPV}$ of one party is positive when the  $\mathrm{NPV}$ of the other is negative:

The lessor (Johnson) expects a positive $\mathrm{NPV}$ of $\$196.83$ and the lessee (Tasha) will have a negative $\mathrm{NPV}$ of $-\$196.83$, even so, Tasha may be willing to accept the leasing contract!

So this is an interesting paradox! to all appearances, there is no way both sides can have a positive **Net Present Value** in a lease contract, but, at the same time, leasing is more and more used in business! 


Apparently, there are some causes that we have not yet studied that are being taken into account when evaluating the feasibility of leasing!
